p.s: The passage at hand definitlydefinitely portrays a big change in the character of Delaney, implying he's an overall round character in the novel, encountering the flattest one, José.
Furthermore, it's a turning point of Delaney's opinion towards Mexican immigrants.
The excerpt is narrated by an omniscient narrator who uses the telling mode to explain the plot.
As a result, there is distance created to the reader since he's not involved in the story and rather observes.
This distance can be a symbol/an allegory standing for the distance Delaney is intenting to put between himself and the Mexican due to being uncomfortable and feeling threatened (l. 31).
The scenic presentation of the plot provides the reader the ability to feel closer to the story and the characters.
Moreover, it creates a more alive athmosphereatmosphere which is a contrast to how Delaney experiences his environment after talking to Todd Sweet.
It's shown that he's overthinking and not interessedinterested in another talk with Sweet he wasn't listening (l. 5).
The reported thoughts of him as well as the climax of him feeling glum, dogless, on his own (l. 7).
The majority of times the narrator uses reported thought as a technique to provide the reader access to Delaney's brain, his impressions, his thoughts and attitude.
This is somehow a paradoxical phenomenon in this scene since the telling mode was used to create distance to the reader and now is being fought with reported thoughts.
These chaotic aspects might represent Delaney's inner feelings though it might be an overinterpretation.

Firstly, Delaney is questioning himself, his beliefs, his morals and attitude (ll. 1) which shows that he is actually a reflective character and notices the impact of his wife Kyra's opinion as well as his ally Jack's opinion.
However, recalling the phantom car (l. 2) that made him feel threatened and fearful is supressing his liberal humanist attitude that's being presented in the beginning of the book.

All the encounters he ever had with Mexicans like the accident in the first of the novel, the time he hit one with his car or his car being stolen resulted in him developpingdeveloping paranoiacparanoid traits as he jumps to conclusions here as well: the trespasser which is what he must have been (l. 14).
The direct speeches demonstrate how he firstly apporaches José carefully (l. 18) and gets more serious and louder after José not responding (l. 28).

For Delaney, him being Mexican is worse than if he'd been a regular trespasser which is shown by the correctio something else, something that struck him with the force of a blow (l. 16) and also is supported by being a personification.
Furthermore, the narrator conveys a specific image of Delaney by using another climax.
After José responds, Delaney feels provoked, threatened and panics (l. 31).
By making comments on José the narrator shows how unimpressed he was, [how] he was mocking [Delaney] (l. 31).
This certain style to write quite interesting since José seems to be supariorsuperior although it should've been the other way around due to racial supremacy of Delaney.
José is described as being annoyed and perceiving Delaney as nothing, a minor annoyance (l. 40).
Furthermore, the change in position implied to in the thesis, is now taking place when Delaney makes a harsh statement on how José [doesn't] belong here (l. 39).
This passage is ambiguity and an allegory since Delaney either refers to the neighborhood or the United States.
Thus, he is being racist and shows how he has finally absorbed the racist attitude of his neighbors.
Another evidence for this circumstance is when Delaney starts approaching him physically and being more violent (l. 42).
This might also be a result of the build up that was created by scenic presentation.
Even though José explains that he's delivering fliesfliers Delaney got so much adrenaline in himself that he's ready for anything (l. 48).
Hence, his racist attitude keeps growing.

The narrator uses negatively connotated words to demonstrate how Delaney is initionally condescending José and doesn't see a difference between being a thief, a liar, the stinking occupant of a stinking sleeping bag in the state forest, a trespasser, a polluter (ll. 49-50) and being a Mexican (l. 50).
Although he tries to seem intimidating and confident, the reader knows that he's in such a desperate state that he'd even feel supported by the presence of a child (l. 52).
Additionally, Delaney's paranoia got him thinking that José carries a weapon and might attack him (l. 55).
The narrator takes Delaney as an example to show how Americans are characterized by having prejudices towards Mexicans and are convinced/believe in cliches and stereotypes.
After realizing that José indeed was no threat, he is stunned and questionquestions himself once again what was happening to him? (ll. 60-61).
Through reported thought the narrator shows that Delaney is actually dehumanizing racists and reducing them to subhuman state What was he becoming?.
Still, the fact that he doesn't even say anything else or apologizes either shows that he's already accepted his new attitude or feels guilty and ashamed for his behavior.

The irony of this passage is the clearaficationclarification at the end of José delivering fliesfliers (as a Mexican) that advertizes for a meeting within the community to discuss the idea of building a wall to keep criminals as well as immigrants out of their residential area and the security and well-being of [them] all (l. 69).
Briefly summarizing all the aspects that have been interpreted in the analysis and re-refering to the thesis, it's clear that this excerpt is the trigger of a new Delaney awakening.
Although he seems to be aware of his actions and opinion in this chapter, he can't help but be impacted by his community such as his wife Kyra or friend Jack.

Thus, his self-presentation and perception as a liberal humanist is ironical and doesn't have any importance or meaning anymore meaning that Delaney lost his main personality trait and now is going to develop new ones.
